Data.event_text: In stock car racing, Joey Logano wins the Daytona 500 (extended to 203 laps due to a green-white-checkered finish), making him the second youngest winner of the race after Trevor Bayne, and giving Team Penske their second Daytona 500 victory. Data.event_text: NASA's MESSENGER spacecraft concludes its four-year orbital mission over Mercury by crashing into the planet at 326 p.m. EDT (1926 GMT) at 14,080 km/h (8,750 mph) at 54.4° N, 149.9° W, near the crater Janáček. NASA confirmed the unobserved impact when the Deep Space Network failed to detect a signal from the spacecraft's beacon, confirming its demise.

links.text: -Mercury Messenger Mission Ends with a Smashing Finale, Universe Today-

Data.event_text: The Obama administration approves the first ferry service from the United States to Cuba in decades, furthering President Obama's efforts to improve relations between the two countries.

Data.event_text: An article published in the London Review of Books by Seymour Hersh alleges that the official account of the Navy SEAL raid in Abbottabad, Pakistan, that killed al-Qaeda leader Osama bin Laden is largely false, and that the Pakistani government was always aware of bin Laden's whereabouts and assisted in the raid itself. The Obama administration later calls the report "baseless".

links.text: -"White House rejects Seymour Hersh 'baseless assumptions' on bin Laden raid". CNN. November 5, 2015. Retrieved May 22, 2015.-

Data.event_text: An Amtrak train derails in the Philadelphia neighborhood for Port Richmond, causing cars to roll over and killing at least 8 people and injuring over 200. The train was later found to have been going nearly twice the speed limit at the time of the incident.

links.text: -"Philadelphia train crash: Amtrak rail accident kills seven". BBC News. March 5, 2015. Retrieved May 14, 2015.-
-"Amtrak driver says he cannot remember deadly crash". BBC News. May 14, 2015. Retrieved May 14, 2015.-

Data.event_text: Dzhokhar Tsarnaev is sentenced to death for committing the 2013 Boston Marathon bombing.

links.text: -"Dzhokhar Tsarnaev Gets Death Penalty in Boston Marathon Bombing". The New York Times. May 15, 2015. Retrieved May 15, 2015.-

Data.event_text: A shootout erupts between rival biker gangs in a Twin Peaks restaurant in Waco, Texas, leaving nine dead.

links.text: -"Shootout among rival biker gangs in Texas restaurant kills 9". The Washington Post. May 17, 2015. Retrieved May 17, 2015.-

Data.event_text: The Federal Trade Commission alleges that four leading cancer charities conned donors out of $187 million over the course of four years, donating only 3% of the money to actual cancer research.

links.text: -"Government says for cancer charities are shams". CNN. May 19, 2015. Retrieved May 19, 2015.-

Data.event_text: David Letterman broadcasts the last episode of his 22-year run as host of The Late Show on CBS, drawing a record audience. He is succeeded as Late Show host by Stephen Colbert.

links.text: -"David Letterman's Late Show finale attracts record audience". CBS News. May 20, 2015. Retrieved June 1, 2015.-

Data.event_text: The State Department begins publishing the e-mails of Hillary Clinton, mostly concerning the 2012 Benghazi attack, that drew controversy earlier in the year when it was revealed that Clinton had been using a private e-mail server for work-related communications during her time as Secretary of State.

links.text: -"First set of Hillary Clinton emails published online". BBC News. May 22, 2015. Retrieved May 22, 2015.-

Data.event_text: California state officials accept an offer from farmers in the SacramentoSan Joaquin River Delta to reduce their water use by 25% during the growing season in response to the severe drought in the area.

links.text: -"Farmers Agree to Water Cuts in California". The New York Times. May 22, 2015. Retrieved May 23, 2015.-

Data.event_text: 25  Historic flash flooding levels occur in Texas and Oklahoma in a prolonged outbreak of floods and tornadoes, leaving at least 17 people dead and at least 40 others missing.

links.text: -"Texas floods: cleanup continues – and so does the search for bodies". CNN. May 27, 2015. Retrieved May 27, 2015.-

Data.event_text: The USA Freedom Act, which aims to end the controversial bulk collection of communication data by the National Security Agency permitted by Section 215 of the USA PATRIOT Act, fails to reach the 60 votes needed to pass in the Senate, despite passing overwhelmingly in the House.

links.text: -"Senate Blocks Bill on N.S.A. Collection of Phone Records". The New York Times. May 23, 2015. Retrieved May 23, 2015.-

Data.event_text: In the IndyCar Series, Juan Pablo Montoya wins the 99th Indianapolis 500. This was this second victory in the race and his first in 15 years, after winning in 2000.
Unidentified criminals use an online service run by the Internal Revenue Service to access the tax information of over 100,000 American taxpayers.

links.text: -"IRS Says Thieves Stole Tax Info From 100,000". ABC News. May 26, 2015. Retrieved May 27, 2015.-

Data.event_text: The Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals denies the Justice Department's request to go forward with President Barack Obama's immigration reform plan that would have effectively blocked the deportation of over 4 million illegal immigrants.

links.text: -"Court sides with Texas against Obama on immigration". CNN. May 27, 2015. Retrieved May 27, 2015.-

Data.event_text: American courts indict fourteen members of FIFA with charges of fraud, money laundering, and racketeering involving tens of millions of dollars over the course of 24 years.

links.text: -"Fifa officials corrupted football – US prosecutors". BBC News. May 27, 2015. Retrieved May 27, 2015.-

Data.event_text: Nebraska Governor Pete Ricketts's veto on state legislators' vote to ban the death penalty in the state is overridden, making Nebraska the first Republican-controlled state to ban the death penalty since 1973.

links.text: -"Nebraska Lawmakers Override Governor's Veto Of Death Penalty Repeal". NPR. May 27, 2015. Retrieved May 27, 2015.-

links.text: -"Rick Santorum joins crowded Republican field for president". BBC News. May 27, 2015. Retrieved May 27, 2015.-

links.text: -"George Pataki Announces Presidential Run". The Huffington Post. May 28, 2015. Retrieved May 28, 2015.-

Data.event_text: Cuba is officially removed from the U.S. State Sponsors of Terrorism list.

links.text: -"US removes Cuba from a list of state sponsors of terror". BBC News. May 29, 2015. Retrieved May 29, 2015.-

links.text: -"Martin O'Malley jumps into presidential race". USA Today. May 30, 2015. Retrieved June 1, 2015.-

links.text: -"Lindsey Graham Jumps Into 2016 Presidential Race: 'Ready to Become Commander-in-Chief On Day One'". ABC News. January 6, 2015. Retrieved January 6, 2015.-

Data.event_text: The USA Freedom Act passes the Senate after several delays and revisions since its inception and is signed into law by President Barack Obama. Though the law does restrict government surveillance under Section 215 of the Patriot Act, it does not completely end bulk collection of American phone metadata, which will now be collected by phone companies who may give information to the NSA voluntarily under the bill.

links.text: -"US Senate votes to curtail bulk data collection". BBC News. February 6, 2015. Retrieved March 6, 2015.-
-"Senate Approves USA Freedom Act After Amendments Fail". NPR. February 6, 2015. Retrieved February 6, 2015.-

Data.event_text: The director of the Transportation Security Administration is reassigned by the Department of Homeland Security after TSA officials were unsuccessful in identifying weapons in screenings 93 percent of the time during a covert test.

links.text: -"Head of T.S.A. Out After Tests Reveal Flaws". The New York Times. February 6, 2015. Retrieved February 6, 2015.-

Data.event_text: Former Rhode Island Governor Lincoln Chafee announces his run for the Democratic nomination in the 2016 presidential election.

links.text: -"Iraq War focus for Lincoln Chafee campaign launch". CNN. March 6, 2015. Retrieved April 6, 2015.-

Data.event_text: Colorado law enforcement destroy the house of an innocent bystander while trying to arrest a shoplifter.

Data.event_text: Former Texas Governor Rick Perry announces his run for the Republican nomination in the 2016 presidential election.

links.text: -"Rick Perry to Run for President in 2016, Shrugging Off 2012 Missteps". The New York Times. April 6, 2015. Retrieved April 6, 2015.-

Data.event_text: Christopher Monfort is convicted of the 2009 Murder of Timothy Brenton, a Seattle police officer. Brenton had been ambushed and shot by Monfort while sitting in his police car. The perpetrator, motivated by an anti-police agenda, was also convicted of two counts of attempted murder and arson.

links.text: -SeattlePI, Levi Pulkkinen (June 3, 2015). "Seattle cop killer convicted in 2009 deadly anti-police spree". seattlepi.com.-

Data.event_text: A pool party in McKinney, Texas receives attention when police officer Eric Casebolt is filmed restraining an unarmed teenage girl on the ground and pointing his weapon at other bystanders. Amid heated debate in the media, Casebolt later resigns.

links.text: -"Texas pool party chaos: 'Out of control' police officer resigns". CNN. June 9, 2015. Retrieved June 10, 2015.-

Data.event_text: The 2015 Belmont Stakes is held at Belmont Park in Elmont, New York, with American Pharoah becoming the first horse in 37 years to win the Triple Crown.

links.text: -"American Pharoah becomes first Triple Crown winner in 37 years". CNN. June 6, 2015. Retrieved August 2, 2015.-

Data.event_text: 2015 Clinton Correctional Facility escape Richard Matt and David Sweat, two convicted murderers, escape from Clinton Correctional Facility in Dannemora, New York, prompting an extensive manhunt. It is the first escape incident at the facility in 150 years.

links.text: -"New York prison escape: How 2 murderers broke out of maximum security". The Los Angeles Times. June 8, 2015. Retrieved June 10, 2015.-
-"How 2 Murderers Escaped From a Maximum Security New York Prison, and the Manhunt That Followed". The New York Times. June 8, 2015. Retrieved June 10, 2015.-

Data.event_text: Former Olympian and television personality Bruce Jenner, coming out as a transgender woman and now going by "Caitlyn", becomes the first transgender person to appear on the cover of Vanity Fair magazine.

links.text: -"Caitlyn Jenner: The Full Story". Vanity Fair. Retrieved January 7, 2015.-
-"Introducing Caitlyn Jenner!". PopSugar. January 6, 2015. Retrieved January 7, 2015.-

Data.event_text: Dee Dee Blanchard is murdered by her daughter Gypsy Rose and her daughter's boyfriend. Dee Dee had abused her daughter for many years, forcing her to use a wheelchair and to pretend to be ill.

links.text: -"The Latest: Missouri Woman Testifies in Boyfriend's Trial". U.S. News. November 15, 2018. Retrieved November 9, 2021.-

Data.event_text: Rachel Dolezal resigns as president of the Spokane, Washington, chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) after allegations that she had lied about her race, claiming to be a black woman when she is actually white.

links.text: -"Rachel Dolezal's story, a study of race and identity, gets 'crazier and crazier' ;Spokane's NAACP leader, Rachel Dolezal, steps down over allegations she isn't black". The Los Angeles Times. June 15, 2015. Retrieved June 15, 2015.-

Data.event_text: Former Florida Governor Jeb Bush announces his run for the Republican nomination in the 2016 presidential election.

links.text: -"Jeb Bush launches 2016 presidential bid". CNN Politics. June 15, 2015. Retrieved June 15, 2015.-

Data.event_text: In the NHL, the Western Conference champion Chicago Blackhawks defeat the Eastern Conference champion Tampa Bay Lightning in six games to win their sixth Stanley Cup championship in franchise history, and their third title in six years.

links.text: -Blackhawks win Stanley Cup as final buzzer sounds. NHL on NBC. The official NHL channel on YouTube. June 15, 2015. Retrieved June 15, 2015.-
-"Blackhawks seize their third Stanley Cup in six seasons". Chicago Tribune. June 16, 2015. Retrieved June 16, 2015.-

Data.event_text: Business magnate and television personality Donald Trump announces his run for the Republican nomination in the 2016 presidential election.

links.text: -"Donald Trump is running for president in 2016". CNN. June 17, 2015. Retrieved June 18, 2015.-

Data.event_text: In the NBA, the Western Conference champion Golden State Warriors defeat the Eastern Conference champion Cleveland Cavaliers in six games to secure their first NBA Finals championship title in 40 years, and their fourth in franchise history.[citation needed]

Nine people are shot and killed during a prayer service at Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church, a historically black church, one of them being church pastor and state senator Clementa C. Pinckney. The accused gunman, 21-year-old white supremacist Dylann Roof, is apprehended by police the next morning.

links.text: -"Charleston Church Shooting Suspect, Dylann Roof, Captured". The New York Times. June 18, 2015. Retrieved June 18, 2015.-

Data.event_text: Treasury Secretary Jack Lew announces that beginning in 2020, an image of a woman will replace that of Alexander Hamilton on the $10 bill, with Lew expecting to choose a woman by the end of this year. Rosa Parks, Harriet Tubman, Eleanor Roosevelt, and Susan B. Anthony have all been considered frontrunners in the consideration.

links.text: -"Move over, Hamilton: woman to appear on $10 bill, Treasury announces". The Guardian. June 17, 2015. Retrieved June 18, 2015.-
-"Woman's Portrait Will Appear on the $10 Bill". The New York Times. June 17, 2015. Retrieved June 17, 2015.-

Data.event_text: Four months after Lester Holt was named interim weeknight anchor of NBC Nightly News in the wake of preceding anchor Brian Williams' suspension for his misrepresentation of certain events, NBC News makes the move permanent, with Holt assuming full-time weeknight duties effective . Holt, who had previously anchored Nightly News' Saturday and Sunday editions from 2007 until Williams' suspension, becomes the first African-American to serve as the sole lead anchor of a weeknight network newscast.

links.text: -"Lester Holt gets anchor chair in historic moment for black journalists". CNN Money. Time Warner. June 18, 2015.-
-"Lester Holt Named Anchor of 'NBC Nightly News'". NBC News. NBCUniversal. June 18, 2015.-

Data.event_text: Delaware Governor Jack Markell signs a bill into law that decriminalizes the possession and private recreational use of up to one ounce of marijuana. Using marijuana in a public place will now yield a $100 civil fine rather than being treated as a misdemeanor.

links.text: -"Delaware is 18th state to allow recreational use of marijuana". The Guardian. June 19, 2015. Retrieved June 19, 2015.-

Data.event_text: Lester Holt replaces a suspended Brian Williams as weeknight anchor of NBC Nightly News. Williams now serves as a breaking news anchor for MSNBC.
Defense Secretary Ashton Carter announces that the US will position tanks and heavy weapons in eastern and central Europe in response to Russia's continued military involvement in Ukraine.

links.text: -"U.S. to pre-position tanks". Reuters. June 23, 2015. Retrieved June 25, 2015.-

Data.event_text: The House of Representatives passes a bill that gives President Barack Obama an authority to negotiate international trade agreements with Congress's approval. It is seen as a stepping stone toward the passing of Obama's proposed trade deal with eleven Asian countries known as the Trans-Pacific Partnership.

links.text: -"Obama scores a major trade win, burnishing his foreign policy legacy". The Washington Post. June 24, 2015. Retrieved June 27, 2015.-

Data.event_text: Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal announces his run for the Republican nomination in the 2016 presidential election.

links.text: -"Bobby Jindal faces uphill fight in crowded 2016 race". CNN. June 24, 2015. Retrieved June 25, 2015.-

Data.event_text: In a 63 decision, the Supreme Court upholds subsidies for the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (also known as Obamacare) nationwide, even in states that did not set up their own insurance exchanges.

links.text: -"Obamacare subsidies preserved in US Supreme Court ruling". BBC News. June 25, 2015. Retrieved June 25, 2015.-
-"Supreme Court upholds ObamaCare subsidies". Fox News. June 25, 2015. Archived from the original on June 25, 2015. Retrieved June 25, 2015.-
-"Supreme Court upholds ObamaCare subsidies". Fox News. June 25, 2015. Archived from the original on June 25, 2015. Retrieved June 25, 2015.-

Data.event_text: In a 54 decision, the U.S. Supreme Court rules that the Constitution guarantees a right to same-sex marriage in the United States. Justice Anthony Kennedy wrote the majority opinion, joined by Justices Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Stephen Breyer, Sonia Sotomayor and Elena Kagan.
Richard Matt, one of two convicted murderers who escaped from the Clinton Correctional Facility in Dannemora, New York, is fatally shot by police in Franklin County.

links.text: -"Richard Matt, Escaped Prisoner in New York Manhunt, Is Fatally Shot". The New York Times. June 26, 2015. Retrieved June 27, 2015.-

Data.event_text: Bree Newsome is taken into custody after climbing the flagpole on the grounds of the South Carolina State House and removing its Confederate flag as an act of protest following the Charleston church shooting ten days earlier. The flag is flown again 45 minutes later.

links.text: -"Confederate flag at South Carolina State House pulled down". BBC News. June 27, 2015. Retrieved June 27, 2015.-

Data.event_text: Convicted murderer David Sweat is shot and apprehended by police near the CanadaUS border 22 days after escaping from the Clinton Correctional Facility in New York.

links.text: -"Escaped New York Prisoner David Sweat Shot, Captured". The Huffington Post. June 28, 2015. Retrieved June 28, 2015.-

Data.event_text: In a 54 ruling, the Supreme Court rules that the use of the chemical midazolam hydrochloride in a drug compound used in executions, which the petitioners argued did not properly sedate prisoners before execution and caused excruciating pain in three botched executions in Oklahoma the year prior, does not violate the cruel and unusual punishment statute of the Eighth Amendment of the United States Constitution.

links.text: -"Supreme Court Allows Use of Execution Drug". The New York Times. June 29, 2015. Retrieved January 7, 2015.-

Data.event_text: In a 54 ruling, the Supreme Court rules that the Environmental Protection Agency's proposed regulations on toxic emissions from American power plants are unreasonable and violate the Clean Air Act.

links.text: -"Supreme Court: EPA unreasonably interpreted the Clean Air Act". CNN. June 29, 2015. Retrieved January 7, 2015.-

Data.event_text: California Governor Jerry Brown signs into law a bill that requires California public or private school children to be vaccinated for various diseases to attend, regardless of their parents' religious objections.

links.text: -"California Governor Signs School Vaccination Law". NPR. June 30, 2015. Retrieved January 7, 2015.-

Data.event_text: President Barack Obama and Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff announce a statement, both agreeing to lower their greenhouse gas emissions and get 20% of their nations' electricity from renewable energy sources by 2030.

links.text: -"In a major moment for climate policy, China, Brazil, and the U.S. all announce new commitments". The Washington Post. June 30, 2015. Retrieved January 7, 2015.-

Data.event_text: The United States Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court approves temporarily resuming the National Security Agency's program of bulk phone metadata collection and surveillance.

links.text: -"Surveillance Court Rules That N.S.A. Can Resume Bulk Data Collection". The New York Times. June 30, 2015. Retrieved January 7, 2015.-

Data.event_text: New Jersey Governor Chris Christie announces his run for the Republican nomination in the 2016 presidential election.

links.text: -"Chris Christie Announces Run, Pledging 'Truth' About Nation's Woes". The New York Times. June 30, 2015. Retrieved January 7, 2015.-

Data.event_text: President Barack Obama announces the full re-establishment of diplomatic ties with Cuba, with the countries planning to reopen embassies in each other's capital cities.

links.text: -"Announcing Cuba Embassy Deal, Obama Declares 'New Chapter'". The New York Times. January 7, 2015. Retrieved January 7, 2015.-

Data.event_text: The US Justice Department begins investigating "possible unlawful coordination by some airlines" in the United States to keep plane ticket prices high.

links.text: -"US airlines investigated over ticket prices". BBC News. January 7, 2015. Retrieved January 7, 2015.-

Data.event_text: Oregon's decriminalization of recreational marijuana goes into effect, making it the fourth US state to legalize marijuana use.

links.text: -"Oregon becomes fourth US state to legalize recreational marijuana". The Guardian. July 1, 2015. Retrieved July 1, 2015.-

Data.event_text: Illegal immigrant Francisco Sanchez is suspected to have killed 32-year-old Kathryn Steinle in San Francisco, sparking criticism of U.S. immigration policy.

BP agrees to pay the Department of Justice an $18.7 billion settlement in reparation for the 2010 BP oil spill that dumped over 125 million gallons of oil into the Gulf of Mexico. The settlement is the largest paid by a single company in US history.

links.text: -"BP to pay £12bn for Gulf oil spill". BBC News. February 7, 2015. Retrieved February 7, 2015.-

Data.event_text: A woman dies of measles at the University of Washington Medical Center, the first measles death in the United States since 2003.

-"First Person Dies of Measles in U.S. Since 2003". TIME. February 7, 2015. Archived from the original on July 3, 2015. Retrieved February 7, 2015.-

Data.event_text: Former Virginia Senator Jim Webb announces his run for the Democratic nomination in the 2016 presidential election.

links.text: -"Jim Webb joins 2016 presidential race". USA Today. February 7, 2015. Retrieved February 7, 2015.-

Data.event_text: The Swiss experimental solar-powered aircraft Solar Impulse completes its 118-hour non-stop flight from Japan, landing in Hawaii. It is the longest successful flight of a solar-powered aircraft in history.

links.text: -"Solar Impulse plane lands in Hawaii". BBC News. March 7, 2015. Retrieved April 7, 2015.-

Data.event_text: The United States beats Japan 52 in the final game of the 2015 FIFA Women's World Cup, making it the highest scoring Women's World Cup game in history. The US is the first country to ever win three Women's World Cup titles.

links.text: -"USA beats Japan 5–2, wins first Women's World Cup title since 1999". Oregon Live. May 7, 2015. Retrieved May 7, 2015.-

Data.event_text: The FBI, U.S. Postal Service, and Indiana State Police seize electronics and other items from the Zionsville, Indiana home of Subway commercial spokesman Jared Fogle.

Data.event_text: Sandra Bland, an African-American woman who had been arrested on  following a minor traffic violation in Waller County, Texas, is found dead in her jail cell.

Iran and a coalition including the United States come to an agreement on the nuclear program of Iran after numerous months of debate, agreeing to lift the United Nations Security Council's sanctions against Iran in exchange for the reduction of Iran's stockpile of enriched uranium by about 98 percent for the next 15 years.

Data.event_text: A street-corner sized sinkhole forms at the intersection of Fifth Avenue and 64th Street in Sunset Park in Brooklyn, New York City, around 730 am, destroying the street corner. links.text: -"Controversy surrounds FDA decision on women's libido drug". CBS News. August 19, 2015. Retrieved August 22, 2015.-

Data.event_text: Jared Fogle, popular spokesman and advertising figure for the American fast food restaurant chain Subway, agrees to plead guilty to charges of paying to have sex with minors and possession of child pornography.

links.text: -"Jared Fogle, Subway ad star, in underage sex guilty plea". BBC News. August 21, 2015. Retrieved August 22, 2015.-

Data.event_text: After an axe attack on cinema-goers in Tennessee earlier in the month, American movie theater chain Regal Entertainment Group announces that it will now perform security bag checks at all its theater venues.

links.text: -"US cinema chain Regal introduces bag search after attacks". BBC News. August 20, 2015. Retrieved August 22, 2015.-

Data.event_text: Extramarital affair dating website Ashley Madison is faced with a $578 million class action lawsuit by two Canadian law firms after the breach of thousands of customers' personal data in July.

links.text: -"Ashley Madison adultery website faces $578m class action over data breach". The Guardian. August 22, 2015. Retrieved August 22, 2015.-

Data.event_text: News reporter Alison Parker and camera operator Adam Ward are shot and killed on live television during an interview in Moneta, Virginia. The shooter, Vester Lee Flanagan (a former colleague of Parker and Ward at station WDBJ in Roanoke), commits suicide several hours later.

links.text: -Eliott C. McLaughlin; Catherine E. Shoichet (August 26, 2015). "Police: Bryce Williams kills self after on-air slayings". CNN. Retrieved July 16, 2016.-

Data.event_text: Officials report that, in the month of July, California residents reduced their water use by 31.3%, exceeding the 25% mandate put in place by Governor Jerry Brown in response to the ongoing drought in the state.

links.text: -"California drought: Water use 'down by 31 percent'". BBC News. August 27, 2015. Retrieved August 28, 2015.-

Data.event_text: McDonald's Corporation and Tyson Foods sever ties with a Tennessee-based farm after an exposé video released by Mercy for Animals depicts farmers stabbing, brutalizing, and stomping on chickens before sending them to companies for consumption.

links.text: -"McDonald's drops nuggets supplier after video shows animal cruelty". The Guardian. August 27, 2015. Retrieved August 28, 2015.-

Data.event_text: Ashley Madison CEO Noel Biderman resigns from his position in response to the growing information coming out of the site's hacking incident a month earlier.

links.text: -"Ashley Madison Chief Just Resigned Over Hacking Scandal". The Huffington Post. August 28, 2015. Retrieved August 28, 2015.-

Data.event_text: At the MTV Video Music Awards, Kanye West announces he's running for president in 2020.

links.text: -Zaru, Deena (August 31, 2015). "Kanye West declares 2020 presidential bid at VMAs | CNN Politics". CNN. Retrieved December 10, 2022.-

Data.event_text: The University of TexasRio Grande Valley is founded in Brownsville, Texas.[citation needed]
A widespread manhunt begins in northern Illinois after three suspects shoot and kill a veteran Fox Lake police officer.

links.text: -"Illinois Manhunt Underway After Officer Is Shot And Killed". The Huffington Post. January 9, 2015. Retrieved January 9, 2015.-

Data.event_text: In a federal court settlement, the state of California agrees to reform its use of solitary confinement in prisons.

links.text: -"California Agrees to Overhaul Use of Solitary Confinement". The New York Times. January 9, 2015. Retrieved January 9, 2015.-

Data.event_text: Colin Kaepernick takes the knee during the national anthem for the first time.

links.text: -"Colin Kaepernick joined by Eric Reid in kneeling for national anthem protest". the Guardian. Associated Press. September 2, 2016. Retrieved September 15, 2022.-

Data.event_text: The United States Olympic Committee chooses Los Angeles, California, as its selection for the American bid for host city of the 2024 Olympic Games.

links.text: -"US Olympic Committee picks Los Angeles for 2024 Olympic bid". BBC News. January 9, 2015. Retrieved January 9, 2015.-

Data.event_text: Kim Davis, a clerk for Rowan County, Kentucky, is found in contempt of court by federal judge David Bunning and jailed for five days for refusing to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples on religious grounds, defying the Supreme Court case legalizing same-sex marriage.

links.text: -"Kim Davis Jailed For Contempt in Kentucky Gay Marriage Dispute". The New York Times. March 9, 2015. Retrieved March 9, 2015.-

Data.event_text: Harvard Law School professor Lawrence Lessig announces his run for the Democratic nomination in the 2016 presidential election.

links.text: -"Harvard Professor Lawrence Lessig Says He's Running for President". ABC News. June 9, 2015. Retrieved September 16, 2015.-

Data.event_text: Stephen Colbert begins his run as the successor to David Letterman as host of The Late Show on CBS.

links.text: -"Review: On 'Late Show' Premiere, Stephen Colbert Tries to Bring Big Back to Late Night". The New York Times. September 9, 2015. Retrieved September 13, 2015.-

Data.event_text: Senate Democrats block a Republican resolution to reject the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action put forward by President Barack Obama regarding the nuclear program of Iran.

links.text: -"Democrats Hand Victory to Obama on Iran Nuclear Deal". The New York Times. October 9, 2015. Retrieved September 13, 2015.-

Data.event_text: Former Governor of Texas Rick Perry drops out of the race for the Republican nomination in the 2016 presidential election.

links.text: -"Rick Perry drops out of US presidential race". BBC News. November 9, 2015. Retrieved September 13, 2015.-

Data.event_text: The Valley wildfire claims at least three lives in Lake County, California, with thousands of people forced to evacuate.[citation needed]
Geography professor Shannon Lamb shoots and kills history professor Ethan Schmidt at Delta State University in Cleveland, Mississippi, before committing suicide.

links.text: -"Delta State University shooting suspect 'killed himself'". BBC News. September 15, 2015. Retrieved September 15, 2015.-

Data.event_text: 2015 Utah floods Widespread flooding in southern Utah claims at least 20 lives.

After sharp criticism and accusations of racial profiling, police in Irving, Texas, drop charges on 14-year-old Ahmed Mohamed, who was suspended from MacArthur High School after authorities believed a reassembled digital clock he brought to school was a makeshift bomb. President Barack Obama also extends an invitation to Mohamed to the White House.

links.text: -"Ahmed Mohamed: No charges for boy, 14, arrested over clock". BBC News. September 16, 2015. Retrieved September 16, 2015.-

Data.event_text: German car manufacturing company Volkswagen is directed by the Obama administration to recall about 500,000 vehicles in the United States after the company is accused of installing software in its diesel-powered cars that allow emissions of 40 times as much polluting exhaust pipe gas as is allowed by the Clean Air Act.

links.text: -"VW is Said to Cheat on Diesel Emissions; U.S. to Order Big Recall". The New York Times. September 18, 2015. Retrieved September 19, 2015.-

Data.event_text: Game of Thrones wins the award for Outstanding Drama Series.

links.text: -"Emmy Award Winners 2015 – Full List". Variety. September 20, 2015. Retrieved March 22, 2021.-

Data.event_text: Veep wins the award for Outstanding Comedy Series.

links.text: -"Emmys 2015: HBO's 'Veep' and Amazon's 'Transparent' Win Big". Fortune. September 21, 2015. Retrieved September 24, 2015.-

Data.event_text: Viola Davis becomes the first African-American woman to win the award for Outstanding Lead Actress in a Drama Series.

links.text: -"Viola Davis Speaks About Her Emmy, Diversity, and Women on TV". The New York Times. September 23, 2015. Retrieved September 24, 2015.-

Data.event_text: Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker drops out of the presidential race.

links.text: -"Scott Walker drops out of 2016 presidential race". CNN Politics. September 21, 2015. Retrieved September 28, 2015.-

Data.event_text: 27  Pope Francis visits Washington, D.C., New York City, and Philadelphia, where he spoke to a joint session of the United States Congress, addressed the United Nations, attended the World Meeting of Families, and held several masses.

links.text: -"Pope Francis holds large mass in Philadelphia to end US visit". BBC News. September 28, 2015. Retrieved September 28, 2015.-

Data.event_text: County clerk Kim Davis once again faces legal action after four couples ask a judge to order Davis to reissue their marriage licenses after she removed her name from them.

links.text: -"Kim Davis case: Kentucky clerk faces new legal challenge". BBC News. September 22, 2015. Retrieved September 24, 2015.-

Data.event_text: Speaker of the House John Boehner announces that he will resign from his position, effective .

links.text: -"John Boehner, House Speaker, Will Resign From Congress". The New York Times. September 25, 2015. Retrieved September 27, 2015.-

Data.event_text: NASA announces that there is strong evidence that liquid water flows on Mars during the summer months, increasing the chance of sustainable life on the planet.

links.text: -"Nasa scientists find evidence of flowing water on Mars". The Guardian. September 28, 2015. Retrieved September 28, 2015.-

Data.event_text: 26-year-old Christopher Harper-Mercer opens fire at Umpqua Community College in Roseburg, Oregon, killing nine people and injuring eight others. It is the largest shooting at a college since the Virginia Tech shooting in 2007.

The SS El Faro, a cargo ship, sinks off the Bahamas after leaving Jacksonville, Florida, two days prior, headed to Puerto Rico. It is the worst cargo shipping disaster involving a U.S.-flagged vessel in more than three decades.

links.text: -"Details of sinking of El Faro cargo ship emerge from U.S. probe". Reuters. May 27, 2016. Retrieved October 1, 2016.-

Data.event_text: The United States Air Force bombs a Doctors Without Borders hospital in Kunduz, Afghanistan, by request of local Afghan forces. The bombing may be in violation of international humanitarian law.

links.text: -"The Aftermath of the Airstrike on Doctors Without Borders". The Atlantic. April 10, 2015. Retrieved July 10, 2015.-

Data.event_text: The Obama administration decides to cease American training of Syrian rebels in the war against the Islamic State.

links.text: -"Obama Administration Ends Effort to Train Syrians to Combat ISIS". The New York Times. September 10, 2015. Retrieved October 10, 2015.-

Data.event_text: WikiLeaks releases a controversial portion of the text of the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a multinational trade agreement in negotiation that is backed by President Obama, that covers policy related to intellectual property rights.

links.text: -"TPP Treaty Full Text: WikiLeaks Releases Trans-Pacific Partnership Intellectual Property Rights Chapter". International Business Times. September 10, 2015. Retrieved October 10, 2015.-

Data.event_text: The California Coastal Commission bans the captive breeding of killer whales at the San Diego facility of SeaWorld.

links.text: -"California Bans Captive Breeding of Killer Whales at SeaWorld". TIME. September 10, 2015. Retrieved September 10, 2015.-

Data.event_text: The first debate for the Democratic Party before the 2016 primaries is held in Las Vegas, Nevada, and broadcast on CNN.

links.text: -"Democratic debate 2015: Hillary Clinton's big night". CNN. October 14, 2015. Retrieved October 18, 2015.-

Data.event_text: President Barack Obama announces that the United States will extend its military presence in Afghanistan until the end of 2017.

links.text: -"US troops to stay in Afghanistan in policy shift". BBC News. October 15, 2015. Retrieved October 18, 2015.-

Data.event_text: Former Virginia Senator Jim Webb drops out of the presidential race.

links.text: -"Jim Webb drops out of Democratic primary race". Yahoo Politics. October 20, 2015. Retrieved October 31, 2015.-

Data.event_text: Vice President Biden announces he will not run for President.

links.text: -"Joe Biden Is Not Running For President In 2016". HuffPost. October 21, 2015. Retrieved September 20, 2022.-

Data.event_text: Hillary Clinton testifies for a second time before the Benghazi Committee and answered members' questions for more than eight hours in a public hearing.
Former Governor of Rhode Island Lincoln Chafee drops out of the presidential race.

links.text: -"Lincoln Chafee drops out of Democratic primary race". CNN Politics. October 23, 2015. Retrieved October 31, 2015.-

Data.event_text: A drunk driver plows into the Oklahoma State Homecoming parade in Stillwater, Oklahoma, killing four people and injuring 34.

A video surfaces online of a student being violently pulled from her chair in a classroom by a police officer at Spring Valley High School in South Carolina, prompting public outcry and an investigation.

links.text: -"US to investigate officer-pupil clash in South Carolina". BBC News. October 28, 2015. Retrieved October 28, 2015.-

Data.event_text: The World Health Organization releases a finding that processed meat such as sausage and ham can cause cancer.

links.text: -"Processed meat causes cancer, says WHO". CNN Money. October 26, 2015. Retrieved October 28, 2015.-

Data.event_text: The United States Senate votes overwhelmingly in favor of the controversial Cybersecurity Information Sharing Act, which would grant companies immunity from lawsuits for sharing personal data with the government for surveillance. The bill has several noted critics, including the American Civil Liberties Union and Edward Snowden.

links.text: -"Senate passes controversial cybsersecurity bill Cisa 74 to 21". The Guardian. October 27, 2015. Retrieved October 27, 2015.-

Data.event_text: A military JLENS blimp from the United States Army breaks loose from its moorings at the Aberdeen Proving Ground in Maryland, and drifts over 16,000 ft above Pennsylvania. F-16 Fighter jets were scrambled to track the blimp that has since deflated, causing widespread power outages from a long cable it dragged along the ground.[citation needed]
Representative Paul Ryan takes over for John Boehner as Speaker of the House of Representatives after being elected following Boehner's resignation.

links.text: -"Paul Ryan Takes Gavel as House Speaker". ABC News. October 29, 2015. Retrieved October 31, 2015.-

Data.event_text: President Barack Obama orders up to fifty US special operations ground troops to be deployed in Syria to fight Islamic State militants.

links.text: -"Obama orders US special forces to 'assist' fight against Isis in Syria". The Guardian. October 30, 2015. Retrieved October 31, 2015.-

Data.event_text: Under new rules from the United States Sentencing Commission, nonviolent drug offenders with reduced jail sentences begin to be released from prison, with the first of many waves totaling nearly 6,000 people, about 1,700 of which are illegal immigrants and may face deportation.

links.text: -"US prisoner release: Nearly 6,000 drug inmates go free". BBC News. October 30, 2015. Retrieved October 31, 2015.-

Data.event_text: In Major League Baseball, the Kansas City Royals defeat the New York Mets in the 2015 World Series 4 games to 1 to win their first championship title in 30 years.

links.text: -"Royals rally, then rout Mets in 12 to take Series". Retrieved July 16, 2016.-

Data.event_text: Harvard Law School professor Lawrence Lessig drops out of the 2016 presidential election.

links.text: -"Lessig drops out of presidential race". Politico. February 11, 2015. Retrieved January 3, 2016.-

Data.event_text: Newspapers report that oil companies knew that burning oil and gas could cause global warming since the 1970s but, nonetheless, funded deniers for years.

Amid increasing racial tension at the school, Tim Wolfe, president of the University of Missouri System, resigns from his position after a football team strike and a University of Missouri student's hunger strike.

links.text: -"Embattled University of Missouri President Tim Wolfe Resigns". The Huffington Post. September 11, 2015. Retrieved November 13, 2015.-

Data.event_text: A suspect is arrested by University of Missouri police for making racially charged violent threats on social media as the university protests continue to gain media attention.

links.text: -"University of Missouri police arrest suspect in social media death threats". The Washington Post. November 11, 2015. Retrieved November 13, 2015.-

Data.event_text: NASA scientists report that human-made carbon dioxide (CO2) continues to increase above levels not seen in hundreds of thousands of years currently, about half of the carbon dioxide released from the burning of fossil fuels remains in the atmosphere and is not absorbed by vegetation and the oceans.

The US Department of Defense announces their belief that an American airstrike in Syria killed Mohammed Emwazi, better known as Jihadi John, who is responsible for numerous recorded beheadings of several hostages of the Islamic State, including American citizens.

links.text: -"'Jihadi John': US 'reasonably certain' strike killed IS militant". BBC News. November 13, 2015. Retrieved November 13, 2015.-

Data.event_text: Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal withdraws from the 2016 presidential election.

links.text: -"Bobby Jindal Drops Out of 2016 Republican Presidential Race". ABC News. November 17, 2015. Retrieved January 3, 2016.-

Data.event_text: The 2015 New Orleans shooting took place at Bunny Friend playground in the Ninth Ward of New Orleans, Louisiana. In conjunction with the music video recorded at an impromptu unauthorized block party, 17 people were injured, with Joseph "Moe" Allen identified as a suspect.

links.text: -"NOPD identifies suspect in Bunny Friend Playground shooting that injured 17 people | New Orleans – WDSU Home". Wdsu.com. November 10, 2015. Retrieved November 28, 2015.-
-"17 now confirmed injured in Bunny Friend shooting". Wwltv.com. November 23, 2015. Archived from the original on November 27, 2015. Retrieved November 28, 2015.-
-"17 now confirmed injured in Bunny Friend shooting". Wwltv.com. November 23, 2015. Archived from the original on November 27, 2015. Retrieved November 28, 2015.-
-"Suspect named in playground mass shooting". Wwltv.com. November 24, 2015. Archived from the original on November 29, 2015. Retrieved November 28, 2015.-
-"Suspect named in playground mass shooting". Wwltv.com. November 24, 2015. Archived from the original on November 29, 2015. Retrieved November 28, 2015.-

Data.event_text: A gunman opens fire at a Planned Parenthood clinic in Colorado Springs, Colorado, killing 3, including a police officer, and injuring 9. After a 5-hour standoff, shooter Robert Lewis Dear surrenders to police.

links.text: -Catherine E. Shoichet; AnneClaire Stapleton; Greg Botelho (November 27, 2015). "Colorado Planned Parenthood shooting: 3 killed". CNN. Retrieved July 16, 2016.-

Data.event_text: 2015 San Bernardino attack 14 people are killed in a terrorist attack at a facility for the mentally disabled in San Bernardino, California. It is the deadliest mass shooting in the United States in 2015, and the deadliest since 2012.
An E. coli outbreak involving over one dozen states and 150 000 products took place.

links.text: -"E. Coli Scare Spreads To Walmart, Starbucks, Target". MSN. Retrieved July 16, 2016.-

Data.event_text: 2015 NFL season In American football, Green Bay Packers quarterback Aaron Rodgers throws a 61-yard Hail Mary pass to tight end Richard Rodgers to give the team a 27-23 victory against the Detroit Lions and advance to 8-4. The pass is the longest game-winning Hail Mary play in National Football League history.

links.text: -"Packers vs. Lions - Game Recap - December 3, 2015 - ESPN".-

Data.event_text: Defense Secretary Ashton Carter announces that all combat roles in the United States military must be opened to women by April 1, 2016.

links.text: -"Defense secretary will tell US military to open all combat jobs to women". The Guardian. March 12, 2015. Retrieved January 3, 2016.-

Data.event_text: Donald Trump calls for a complete ban on Muslims entering the United States, following the events in San Bernardino and Paris, causing nationwide controversy.

links.text: -"Donald J. Trump Statement On Preventing Muslim Immigration". DonaldJTrump.com. July 12, 2015. Archived from the original on May 8, 2017. Retrieved January 3, 2016.-
-"Donald J. Trump Statement On Preventing Muslim Immigration". DonaldJTrump.com. July 12, 2015. Archived from the original on May 8, 2017. Retrieved January 3, 2016.-

Data.event_text: Pharmaceutical executive Martin Shkreli is revealed to be the winner of the auction of the single copy of the Wu-Tang Clan album Once Upon a Time in Shaolin, valued at $2 million.

links.text: -"Pharma's Bad Boy Exec Paid $2 Million for Wu-Tang Clan's New Record". Bloomberg.com. Bloomberg Businessweek. September 12, 2015. Retrieved January 3, 2016.-

Data.event_text: 2015 Los Angeles Unified School District closure The Los Angeles Unified School District received a credible terrorism threat causing the temporary closure of all Los Angeles Unified Schools.

links.text: -"All Los Angeles Unified schools closed by 'credible threat' of violence". MSN. Retrieved July 16, 2016.-
-Times, Los Angeles (December 16, 2015). "L.A. schools to reopen Wednesday; threat against schools was 'not credible,' officials say". Los Angeles Times. Retrieved July 16, 2016.-

Data.event_text: Martin Shkreli is arrested on securities fraud charges for running a Ponzi-like scheme.

links.text: -"Martin Shkreli, Pharma Executive, Arrested on Fraud Charges". Wall Street Journal. December 17, 2015. Retrieved January 3, 2016.-

Data.event_text: Star Wars The Force Awakens releases in the United States, the seventh film in the mainline Star Wars film series. Grossing over $2 billion worldwide, the film broke box office records and would go on to become the highest-grossing film in the U.S. and the high-grossing of the year.
South Carolina Senator Lindsey Graham drops out of the 2016 presidential election.

links.text: -"Lindsey Graham Drops Out of 2016 Republican Presidential Race". ABC News. December 21, 2015. Retrieved January 3, 2016.-

Data.event_text: Former New York Governor George Pataki drops out of the 2016 presidential election.

links.text: -"George Pataki drops out of 2016 presidential race". Mashable. December 29, 2015. Retrieved January 3, 2016.-

Data.event_text: An arrest warrant issued for comedian Bill Cosby for the alleged drugging and sexual assault of an employee at Temple University in 2004, following over a year of dozens of similar allegations. Cosby remains free on $1 million bail until his trial begins.

links.text: -"Arrest Warrant Issued for Bill Cosby for Alleged 2004 Sexual Assault". People. December 31, 2015. Retrieved January 3, 2016.-
